text:
Situation A. Equally Likely?

The list below gives several actions and possible results. In each case,

  1. Decide whether the possible outcomes are equally likely and explain why.
  2. For those that are equally likely, is the probability 1/2 (or 50%)? Explain your reasoning.

tiles.title: Situation A: Which Outcomes are Equally Likely?

content.name: Situation A: Which Outcomes are Equally Likely?

tiles.title: Situation A: Which Outcomes are Equally Likely

content.name: Situation A Solutions: Which Outcomes are Equally Likely

text:
Situation B. Kaleb Considers Another Experiment

Suppose three members of Kaleb’s family each write their name on a separate card. Kaleb writes his name on 10 cards. The cards are put in a hat and mixed up.

  • Is each card equally likely to be chosen? Is each name equally likely to be chosen?

Each card is equally likely to be chosen.

Each name is not equally likely to be chosen. Because Kaleb has more cards with his name, there are more chances to pick a card with his name.

P(Kaleb’s name) = 10/13

P(family member 1) = 1/13

P(family member 2) = 1/13

P(family member 3) = 1/13
• How many cards should each family member add to the hat so that each name is equally likely to be chosen? How many total cards are there now?

If Kaleb leaves his 10 cards in the hat, then each person should put their name in for a total of 10 times. So, each person other than Kaleb needs to add 9 cards.

Now, the hat would have 40 cards with each name equally likely to be chosen.

P(Kaleb’s name) = 10/40

P(family member 1) = 10/40

P(family member 2) = 10/40

P(family member 3) = 10/40

dataSet.name: Situation A: Which Outcomes are Equally Likely

attributes.name: Action
values: You toss an empty juice can.
If it snows tomorrow, school will closed.
You flip a light switch.
A baby is born.
A high school soccer teams plays a game.
You guess an answer on a true or false test.
You randomly pick a marker out of a box.

attributes.name: Possible Outcomes
values: The can lands on its side, the can lands upside down, or the can lands right side up.
It snows or it does not snow.
The light goes on or the light goes off.
The baby is right-handed, or the baby is left-handed.
The team wins or the team loses.
You randomly mark true or you mark false.
There are 8 markers, one of each color. You get a black, brown, blue, purple, red, orange, yellow, or green.

attributes.name: Equally Likely?
values: SOLUTIONS
The results are not equally likely. An empty juice can is more likely to land on its side than on either of its ends.
The results are not equally likely. In places where it snows often, school does not close with every snow. In places where snow is rare, it may be likely that school will close if it snows.
The results are equally likely. The probability of turning the light on or off is ½.
The results are not equally likely. More people are right-handed than left-handed.

The results are not equally likely, as the team and its opponent are probably not evenly matched. However, if sports analysts are saying the game is an even match, then winning or losing might be considered equally likely.
The results are equally likely. There is a 50% chance of guessing the correct answer.
Choosing each marker is equally likely. There is not a 50% probability. There is a 1 out of 8 chance of selecting each color.
SOLUTIONS END
